citation.article-title: Clostridium thermocopriae sp. nov., a cellulolytic thermophile from animal feces, compost, soil, and a hot spring in Japan.

p.s: Clostridium thermocopriae sp. nov.
Clostridium thermocopriae (ther. mo. co' pri.ae. Gr.n. thermos, heat; Gr.n. kupria, compost; M.L. gen.n. thermocopriae of heat compost).
Straight rods, 0.4 to 0.7 μm wide by 2.0 to 8.0 μm long (type strain, 0.5 to 0.7 by 2.2 to 6.0 μm) in PY medium containing 1% cellobiose after growth for 18 h at 55 to 60μC.
These organisms produce terminal spherical endospores (diameter, 1.2 to 1.6 μm) which swell the cells.
Gram negative.
Colonies on cellulose agar medium are smooth and 1 to 2 mm in diameter and have clear zones (diameter, 2 to 4 mm) showing complete solubilization of cellulose within 3 to 6 days.
Strictly anaerobic.
The optimum temperature for growth is about 60°C; growth occurs at 47 to 74°C.
The pH range for growth is 6.0 to 8.0; the optimum pH is 6.5 to 7.3.
Indole is not produced.
Esculin is hydrolyzed.
Nitrate is not reduced.
Gelatin is not digested.
The type strain and two other strains hydrolyze starch.
The type strain and three other strains produce curd in milk.
These organisms utilize cellulose, hemicellulose, cellobiose, glucose, fructose, maltose, and mannose; the final pH in PY broth is 5.2 to 5.9 (Table 1).
The pH of modified CM3 broth supplemented with cellobiose is 4.9 to 5.3 after incubation for 2 days.
The type strain and four other strains utilize arabinose, lactose, and trehalose.
The type strain and three other strains utilize glycogen and amygdalin.
Melibiose and mannitol are not utilized.
In the fermentation of carbohydrates, carbon dioxide, hydrogen, ethanol, and acetic, butyric, and lactic acids are produced, but propionic and valeric acids are not produced.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA is 36.7 to 37.8 mol% (type strain, 37.2 mol%).
Isolated from camel feces, compost, soil, and a hot spring in Japan (Table 2).
The type strain is strain JT3-3 (=IAM 13577) (Fig. 1).
